description:
Cololabis saira, commonly known as the Pacific saury or sanma, is a species of small, slender fish belonging to the family Scomberesocidae. It is found in the temperate and subtropical waters of the Pacific Ocean, primarily along the coasts of Japan, China, and North America.

The Pacific saury is characterized by its elongated, rounded body shape, a long, narrow beak-like snout, and a forked tail. It typically ranges in length from 20 to 30 centimeters (8 to 12 inches) and has a greenish-blue or silvery-blue coloration on its back, with a lighter, silvery-white underside.

The Pacific saury is an important commercial and recreational fish, valued for its flavorful flesh and high-fat content, which makes it a popular food item in many Asian cuisines. It is caught using a variety of fishing methods, including purse seining, driftnetting, and trolling.

Ecologically, the Pacific saury plays a significant role in the marine food web, serving as a key forage species for larger predatory fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Its migration patterns and population dynamics are closely linked to changes in oceanic conditions, making it an important indicator species for monitoring the health of marine ecosystems.
